skill.name: professional-communication
skill.description: Guide technical communication for software developers. Covers email structure, team messaging etiquette, meeting agendas, and adapting messages for technical vs non-technical audiences. Use when drafting professional messages, preparing meeting communications, or improving written communication.
skill.summary: Guide technical communication for software developers. Covers email structure, team messaging etiquette, meeting agendas, and adapting messages for different audiences.
skill.author: softaworks

security_audit.summary: All 95 static findings are false positives. The scanner misidentified markdown code block backticks as shell execution commands. This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown files with communication frameworks, email templates, and best practices. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or system access.

content.value_statement: Software developers often struggle to communicate technical concepts clearly to different audiences. This skill provides proven frameworks, templates, and best practices for writing effective emails, team messages, meeting agendas, and adapting technical language for non-technical stakeholders.
actual_capabilities: Generate structured email templates for status updates, requests, and escalations
Provide frameworks for adapting technical language for non-technical audiences
Create meeting agenda templates with clear objectives and action items
Offer team messaging best practices including async communication guidelines
Apply the What-Why-How structure to organize any professional message
Improve writing clarity through active voice and elimination of filler words
limitations: Does not send emails or messages on your behalf
Does not integrate with email clients or team messaging platforms
Cannot attend meetings or take notes during discussions
Does not provide grammar or spell checking

use_cases.title: Drafting stakeholder update emails
use_cases.description: Software team leads need to communicate project progress to non-technical business stakeholders. This skill provides templates that emphasize business impact and outcomes over technical implementation details.

use_cases.title: Preparing effective meeting agendas
use_cases.description: Product managers and project coordinators need structured meeting agendas that ensure productive discussions and clear action items. The skill provides templates for standups, retrospectives, and architecture reviews.

use_cases.title: Translating technical concepts
use_cases.description: Senior developers and architects need to explain complex technical decisions to non-technical stakeholders. The skill provides jargon simplification guides and audience calibration frameworks.

prompt_templates.title: Write a status update email
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a professional status update email about [project/topic] for [audience]. Include: 1) overall progress summary, 2) completed items, 3) current blockers, 4) next steps. Use the What-Why-How structure. Keep it concise and scannable.
prompt_templates.scenario: Drafting a regular project status email

prompt_templates.title: Simplify technical explanation
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain [technical concept or decision] to [non-technical audience] such as executives or customers. Avoid jargon. Focus on business value and impact. Use analogies where helpful.
prompt_templates.scenario: Simplifying technical concepts for non-technical stakeholders

prompt_templates.title: Prepare meeting agenda
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a structured meeting agenda for [meeting type] about [topic]. Include: meeting objective, agenda items with time estimates, preparation requirements for attendees, and expected outcome. The meeting is [duration] with attendees [list].
prompt_templates.scenario: Preparing for a team meeting or review

prompt_templates.title: Draft escalation email
prompt_templates.prompt: Write an escalation email about [issue/problem] to [stakeholder]. Include: issue summary, business impact, solutions already attempted, and what decision or action is needed from the recipient. Be clear but professional.
prompt_templates.scenario: Escalating a critical issue that requires management attention

output_examples.input: Write a status update email about the API migration project for the executive team
output: Subject: API Migration: Week 8 Update - On Track for Q2 Completion
The API migration project remains on track with 75% completion. Key milestone reached last week: all customer-facing endpoints successfully migrated.
- Partner integrations: 75% complete (3 of 4 partners migrated)
- Legacy system decommission: On hold until partner migration finishes
**Risk:** One partner (15% of traffic) needs additional security review. Expected resolution: 2 weeks.
**Next Steps:** Complete partner migrations by Week 10, then begin legacy decommission.
Questions? Happy to discuss in detail.

output_examples.input: Explain microservices to a non-technical stakeholder
output: Think of our system like a small city instead of a single large building.
Each service (payment, user accounts, search) operates independently.
- If one part needs updates, we can change it without disrupting the others
- We can add more resources to busy areas without upgrading everything
- Problems in one area don't bring down the entire system
The result: Faster updates and more reliable service for you.

best_practices: Start every professional message with a clear purpose statement. Recipients should understand your intent within 5 seconds.
Use the What-Why-How structure for any communication requiring action or decision. Always explain context before making requests.
Calibrate your language to your audience. Technical details belong in communications with engineers; business impact belongs in communications with stakeholders.
anti_patterns: Sending long paragraphs without structure. Use bullets, headers, and short paragraphs to make messages scannable.
Using technical jargon when communicating with non-technical audiences. Always translate concepts into business value.
Starting messages with greetings like 'Hey' or 'Hi' without context. The 'No Hello' principle: get to your point immediately.

faq.question: What tools does this skill integrate with?
faq.answer: This is a guide-only skill. It does not integrate with email clients or messaging platforms. It provides frameworks and templates that you apply when writing in any tool.

faq.question: Can this skill help me write customer-facing communications?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill includes guidance on adapting technical content for non-technical audiences and simplifying jargon. Use the jargon translation tables and audience calibration framework.

faq.question: Does this skill check my writing for grammar?
faq.answer: No. The skill focuses on structure, clarity, and professional tone. It does not perform grammar or spell checking.

faq.question: How is this skill different from writing assistants?
faq.answer: Writing assistants focus on grammar and style. This skill focuses on communication strategy: what to say, how to structure it, and who your audience is.

faq.question: Can I use this for Slack or Teams messages?
faq.answer: Yes. The team messaging section covers async communication best practices, thread usage, and the 'No Hello' principle for efficient team chat.

faq.question: What meeting types are supported?
faq.answer: The skill covers standups, sprint retrospectives, architecture reviews, planning sessions, and stakeholder updates. Each has a structured template.
